questions.text: A 23-year-old man is admitted to the hospital for observation because of a headache, dizziness, and nausea that started earlier in the day while he was working. He moves supplies for a refrigeration company and was handling a barrel of carbon tetrachloride before the symptoms began. He was not wearing a mask. One day after admission, he develops a fever and is confused. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F). Serum studies show a creatinine concentration of 2.0 mg/dL and alanine aminotransferase concentration of 96 U/L. This patient's laboratory abnormalities are most likely due to which of the following processes?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Glutathione depletion results in increased vulnerability to free radical injury, which can result in CNS toxicity, hepatotoxicity, and nephrotoxicity as seen in this case. Glutathione stores can be depleted by NAPQI that forms as a result of acetaminophen toxicity. It is not the mechanism underlying CCl4 toxicity.

B) INCORRECT:

Metabolites of certain compounds can serve as haptens and cause immune-mediated drug-induced liver injury (DILI), which typically manifests with fever and abnormal liver function tests but would not cause the CNS toxicity and nephrotoxicity seen in this case. Metabolite haptenization is induced by agents such as acetaminophen, certain antibiotics (e.g., amoxicillin-clavulanate, tetracyclines), and statins. It is not the mechanism underlying CCl4 toxicity.

C) INCORRECT:

Protoporphyrin accumulation is a feature of lead poisoning due to inhibition of the enzyme ferrochelatase, which converts protoporphyrin into heme. Lead poisoning can cause headache, nausea, confusion, and nephrotoxicity as seen in this case. However, it typically manifests less acutely; hepatotoxicity would not be expected. Protoporphyrin accumulation is not associated with CCl4 toxicity.

D) INCORRECT:

Stabilization of polymerized microtubules is the mechanism of action of taxanes (e.g., paclitaxel). Side effects of these compounds include myelosuppression and neuropathy, but not nephrotoxicity and hepatotoxicity. Microtubule stabilization is not the mechanism underlying CCl4 toxicity.

E) CORRECT:

CCl4 is a halogenated hydrocarbon with a characteristically sweet odor that can enter the body through the skin, respiratory tract, and gastrointestinal tract. The cytochrome-P450 system converts CCl4 into trichloromethyl (CCl3) free radicals that cause lipid peroxidation, protein dysfunction, and DNA breakage. This initially manifests with injuries to the CNS (e.g., sedation, headache, polyneuropathy, encephalopathy) and later involves the liver (e.g., fatty changes, congestion, centrilobular necrosis), kidney (e.g., acute kidney injury), and heart (e.g., arrhythmias).

Other causes of free radical damage include iron toxicity (e.g., hemochromatosis), copper toxicity (e.g., Wilson disease), oxygen toxicity (e.g., retinopathy of prematurity), and drug toxicity (via the depletion of free radical scavengers).
questions.hint: This patient has symptoms of carbon tetrachloride (CCl4) toxicity (e.g., fever, confusion, acute kidney injury, elevated ALT). CCl4 causes free radical injury and is found in old refrigerants, dry-cleaning fluids, and propellants.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old boy presents to the emergency department after drinking an unidentified liquid 30 minutes before arrival. His father was organizing his tools in the garage when his son started drinking from an old plastic water bottle filled with clear liquid. The child cried immediately, vomited once, and has been coughing intermittently since then. He has been refusing to drink or eat but is consolable. The father reports that the substance had a strong odor but did not look or smell like bleach; he thinks that it was from an old automotive project.
The child is otherwise healthy. He was born full-term without complications, has no medical problems, does not take any medications, and has no allergies.
He has a temperature of 37.2°C, a heart rate of 145 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 34 breaths per minute, a blood pressure of 95/50 mm Hg, and an oxygen saturation of 94% while breathing ambient air. He is alert and crying when approached, with clear rhinorrhea and slightly injected conjunctivae bilaterally. He has a distinct odor on his clothes. Pulmonary examination reveals intermittent rhonchi and faint coarse crackles in the right upper lung field. He does not exhibit grunting, nasal flaring, or suprasternal retractions.
A chest radiograph reveals faint scattered opacities in the right upper lobe; other lung fields are clear.
In addition to close monitoring of this patient’s hemodynamic and respiratory status, which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient’s clinical status does not necessitate rapid sequence intubation (RSI) at this time. Indications for RSI in this scenario would include severe respiratory distress with evidence of respiratory failure or severely altered mental status (lethargy, coma).

B) INCORRECT:

Emergency endoscopy can be indicated for caustic ingestions but is not a priority in a typical hydrocarbon ingestion. Hydrocarbons evaporate rapidly and travel into the airway with inhalation. As such, they are more likely to cause acute bronchopulmonary irritation and injury than gastroesophageal injury.

C) CORRECT:

This patient’s exposure history and clinical presentation are consistent with hydrocarbon poisoning.

Hydrocarbon exposures in children typically occur through accidental ingestion of household substances or, in adolescents, intentional inhalation. Common sources of hydrocarbon exposure include gasoline, propellants, motor oils, lighter fluids, lamp oils, and mineral spirits. Hydrocarbons are rapidly absorbed through mucous membranes and are also easily aspirated because of their low viscosity and high volatility.

During initial management of hydrocarbon exposure, a chest radiograph is important, given the high risk for chemical pneumonitis, and the patient’s respiratory status should be monitored closely. Hydrocarbons disrupt alveolar surfactant, thereby leading to reduced pulmonary compliance. Direct pneumocyte injury and subsequent inflammatory response can cause rapidly progressive alveolar collapse, interstitial edema, and even alveolar hemorrhage.

Patients exposed to hydrocarbons should also undergo initial electrocardiography (ECG) and be monitored by ECG for at least 6 hours after the exposure. Hydrocarbons cause an increased sensitivity of the myocardium to endogenous epinephrine. They can precipitate both tachy- and bradyarrhythmias, diminished inotropy, and nonperfusing rhythms such as ventricular fibrillation. ECG can identify signs of atrioventricular block, ST-segment elevation, and premature ventricular contractions.

Key learning point: In addition to having their hemodynamic and respiratory status carefully monitored, all children with suspected hydrocarbon poisoning should be evaluated with a chest radiograph and an electrocardiogram, because ingestion or inhalation of hydrocarbon predisposes patients to arrhythmia.

D) INCORRECT:

Emergency bronchoscopy is not indicated in this patient. Indications for bronchoscopy in hydrocarbon exposures include hemoptysis, suspected foreign-body aspiration, and tracheobronchial injury.

E) INCORRECT:

Activated charcoal is not recommended for hydrocarbon ingestion, as it can induce vomiting, which increases the risk of aspiration.

questions.text: A 28-year-old mechanic presents 3 hours after accidentally inhaling gasoline vapors in an enclosed workspace. She reports cough, nausea, and one episode of vomiting. Vital signs are T, 37.2°C (99.0°F); P, 102; BP, 142/85; R, 22; oxygen saturation, 92% on room air. She appears mildly confused and has bilateral lung crackles. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nasogastric decompression is not indicated in patients with hydrocarbon toxicity. The patient's symptoms are primarily related to inhalation exposure and respiratory compromise and require supportive care.

B) INCORRECT:

Whole bowel irrigation is not indicated for hydrocarbon toxicity. This intervention does not address the primary respiratory toxicity from vapor inhalation.

C) INCORRECT:

Induced emesis is not recommended in patients with hydrocarbon exposure. Current toxicology guidelines discourage the use of ipecac because benefits are minimal and it can cause complications.

D) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient's clinical presentation is consistent with hydrocarbon toxicity, which can manifest with respiratory symptoms. Supportive care with oxygen therapy is appropriate for this patient with signs of respiratory compromise with hypoxia.

E) INCORRECT:

Activated charcoal is an ineffective treatment for hydrocarbon toxicity as organic solvents are not well absorbed by charcoal. Additionally, administration in a patient with altered mental status poses a risk for aspiration.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man is brought to the ED after being found unconscious in a poorly ventilated room where trichloroethylene degreasing solution had been used. Upon arrival, his Glasgow Coma Scale score is 8 and he has irregular respirations. Vital signs are BP, 130/68; P, 99; R, 8; oxygen saturation, 85% on room air. Physical examination shows bilateral rhonchi. He responds only to painful stimuli. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Naloxone is used for opioid overdose reversal. While the patient has CNS depression, hydrocarbon toxicity from trichloroethylene does not respond to naloxone, and the mechanism of toxicity is different from opioid-induced respiratory depression.

B) INCORRECT:

High-flow nasal cannula provides supplemental oxygen but does not address the underlying problem of hypoventilation and altered mental status. This patient needs definitive airway management given the risk of complete respiratory failure from neurotoxic effects.

C) INCORRECT:

Activated charcoal is used for certain ingested toxins but is not indicated for inhaled hydrocarbon exposure. Additionally, charcoal would be contraindicated in a patient with altered mental status due to aspiration risk.

D) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient has severe CNS depression (GCS 8) with hypoventilation and hypoxia from trichloroethylene toxicity. Chlorinated alkenes cause CNS depression, which manifests with drowsiness, ataxia, coma, central respiratory depression, and respiratory tract irritation. Immediate airway protection via endotracheal intubation is essential in a patient with altered mental status and inadequate ventilation to prevent further deterioration and cardiac arrest.

E) INCORRECT:

Hyperbaric oxygen therapy is primarily used for carbon monoxide poisoning, not hydrocarbon toxicity. This patient requires immediate airway stabilization before any adjunctive therapies are considered.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up appointment for his type 2 diabetes mellitus. He reports that his vision has been progressively worsening over the past several months, and he has also developed numbness and tingling in his feet. Medical history is significant for ischemic heart disease, peripheral neuropathy, and chronic lymphocytic leukemia. He is retired and lives in Texas with his wife. He served in the US Army during the Vietnam War. Current medications are metformin, atorvastatin, and clopidogrel. He does not smoke or drink alcohol and jogs outdoors almost daily for 20 minutes. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows bilateral retinopathy. Neurological examination shows decreased sensation in a stocking-glove distribution in both lower extremities. Which of the following is the most likely additional long-term health risk associated with this patient's history?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs recognizes several conditions associated with Agent Orange exposure, including cancers (e.g., chronic lymphocytic leukemia, Hodgkin lymphoma, non-Hodgkin lymphoma) and noncancer conditions (e.g., type 2 diabetes mellitus, ischemic heart disease, Parkinson disease, peripheral neuropathy). Epidemiological studies have demonstrated an increased incidence of Parkinson disease among soldiers exposed to Agent Orange, which is thought to be due to dioxin-induced neurotoxicity affecting dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra. Recognizing this association is essential for screening and early intervention.

B) INCORRECT:

Environmental factors associated with an increased risk of developing systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) include tobacco products and silica exposure. This patient has no smoking history or relevant silica exposure. His military service may have involved exposure to Agent Orange, which is not a risk factor for SLE.

C) INCORRECT:

While military service may increase the risk of respiratory diseases through exposure to, e.g., tobacco smoke or burn pits, this patient has no history of smoking or extensive exposure to air pollution or fine dusts. His military service is more likely to have involved exposure to Agent Orange, which is not a risk factor for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Environmental factors associated with multiple sclerosis include low vitamin D levels and tobacco products. As this patient exercises outdoors almost daily, vitamin D deficiency is unlikely. Furthermore, he has no smoking history. It is more likely that this patient's military service involved exposure to Agent Orange, which is not a risk factor for multiple sclerosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Environmental factors associated with an increased risk of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) include tobacco products and certain occupational or environmental exposures (e.g., lead, pesticides). This patient has no history of smoking or significant occupational exposures known to increase the risk of ALS. His military service may have involved exposure to Agent Orange, which is not a risk factor for ALS.
questions.hint: This patient is at increased risk for conditions associated with Agent Orange exposure, which was used in the Vietnam War.
